abstract.p: Letter by Philip Nobile on April 14 comment about his plagiarism charge against Jack Heidenry for book What Wild Ecstasy; reports remedies he has won from Heidenry and Simon & Schuster (S)

block.p: Re your April 14 Business Day article on my plagiarism charge against Jack Heidenry in ''What Wild Ecstasy: The Rise and Fall of the Sexual Revolution'':
Re your April 14 Business Day article on my plagiarism charge against Jack Heidenry in ''What Wild Ecstasy: The Rise and Fall of the Sexual Revolution'':
Simon & Schuster has agreed to do more than just list articles of mine in future editions.
Rebecca Saletan, Mr. Heidenry's editor, has agreed to put quotation marks around passages copied from my New York magazine article on Gay Talese.

As she conceded in a letter on March 24, ''the corresponding text will be further amended in places to quote you directly (within limits of fair use, of course), in order to further clarify Heidenry's reliance on your account in this brief passage.''
Moreover, you misconstrued my failure to sue Mr. Heidenry when you wrote that ''even Mr. Nobile is not charging copyright infringement.''

Indeed, I believe that I have a strong case for copyright infringement, the legal term for plagiarism. I sent Simon & Schuster several parallels from six of my works, four of which were suspiciously uncited in Mr. Heidenry's end notes.
But as I told your reporter, I abhor using the ax of the law when other remedies exist -- like exposing Mr. Heidenry's piracy in the courtroom of journalism.
What's the Moral of a Story on Plagiarism?
